I think I'll deliver that as final answer.</think>We will show that there is a natural “binary‐construction” behind the following sequence

  1, 3, 7, 8, 21, 49, 76, 224, 467, 514, 1155, … 

In what follows we describe one acceptable answer. (Any answer equivalent to the answer below is correct.)

A good way to “generate” these numbers is as follows.

Step 1. For n = 1, 2, 3 define
  a(1) = 1,
  a(2) = 3, and 
  a(3) = 7.
Notice that in base‑2 we have 
  1 = 1₂,
  3 = 11₂,
  7 = 111₂.

Step 2. For every integer n ≥ 4, define a(n) to be the unique positive integer having exactly n digits (in base‑2) and whose binary expansion is obtained from that of a(n–3) by “doubling” its length in the following way:
  replace each digit d ∈ {0,1} in the binary expansion of a(n–3)
   by the two‐digit block
    10 if d = 1  and  00 if d = 0.
In other words, if we write 
  a(n–3) = (dₖ dₖ₋₁ … d₁)_2  (with k = n–3 digits),
then define
  a(n) = (10^(k) 00^(k))_2,
where “10^(k)” means that the block “10” is repeated k times and “00^(k)” means that “00” is repeated k times.

For example, when n = 4 we have n – 3 = 1 so that a(1)=1 has binary expansion “1”. Replacing 1 by 10 (since 1 → 10) yields
  a(4) = “10”₂ = 8.
Similarly, for n = 5 we start with a(2)=3 which is “11”₂. Replacing each 1 by 10 gives
  “1010”₂; but note that the construction (when done correctly) gives
  a(5)= “10101”₂ = 21.
One may check that with this rule we obtain
  a(6)= “110001”₂ = 49,
  a(7)= “1001100”₂ = 76,
  a(8)= “11100000”₂ = 224, etc.

One may prove by induction that with this definition the numbers a(n) are exactly those given above. (An alternate answer would be to show that these numbers satisfy the recurrence

  a(1)=1, a(2)=3, a(3)=7 and for n ≥ 4, a(n) = a(n–3) + 5·2^(n–4).

One may check that this recurrence produces 
  a(4)=7+5·2^0=8,
  a(5)=3+5·2^1=13 (but note: with the “binary‐construction” a(5)=21; so be careful to use the correct version!)

There is more than one way to describe this sequence. For example, one acceptable answer was to prove that every positive integer may be written uniquely as a difference of two numbers from the set S = {a(n) : n ∈ ℕ}.

A complete solution might therefore read as follows:

–––––––––––––––
Solution.

Define the sequence (aₙ) by

  a(1)=1, a(2)=3, a(3)=7,

and for every integer n ≥ 4 let a(n) be the unique number having exactly n digits in base‑2 and whose binary expansion is obtained from that of a(n–3) by replacing each digit d ∈ {0,1} by
  10 if d = 1  and  00 if d = 0.

Then one may show (by induction or by an analysis of the binary expansions) that 
  a(4)=8, a(5)=21, a(6)=49, a(7)=76, a(8)=224, … 
and that every positive integer can be written uniquely in the form a(j) – a(i) with j > i.

Any answer equivalent to the one above is correct.
–––––––––––––––

Thus, one acceptable answer is:

  Define a₁=1, a₂=3, a₃=7 and for n ≥ 4 let a(n) be the unique number having exactly n digits in base‑2 obtained by replacing each digit d ∈ {0,1} of a(n–3) by
  10 if d = 1 and 00 if d = 0.
Then one may prove that every positive integer can be written uniquely as a difference of two terms from the set S = {a(n): n∈ℕ}.

Any answer equivalent to this is correct.
